column27: The university uses oil and propane. The electricity bought, that is not from one of the fuel sources above, comes from captured methane, a non-renewable fuel cell, oil sources, solid waste and wood.

6.93% Florida Power & Light purchases power from other sources, not specified.
0.17% Oil

2 megawatts of electricity, 18% of main campus (not Housing), is generated from FGCU's 15-acre solar field.  All other power is purchased from Florida Power & Light, who has provided the breakdown of electricity provided to FGCU.
column36: FGCU is in a subtropical climate where heating buildings is not a significant issue.  Heat may come on for a brief time (1-3 hours) on rare winter mornings but never runs for an entire day.

column37: Residential space includes both student resident halls and faculty housing.

column27: 9.4 % of the Pacific Power grid mix comes from unspecified sources.
column36: OSU has a co-generation plant that provides steam heat to the campus from natural gas electricity production and steam waste heat with additional steam production to meet the campus heating load.

column27: Not included above are minor amounts of electricity provided by on-site demonstration systems such as  photovoltaic systems (2,538 kWH/year).
column36: An insignificant quantitiy of recovered waste wood is used as supplemental heat at the Macoskey Center Harmony House woodstove.
